title: 112_hr6128
content: The "Help Separated Families Act of 2012" ensures that immigration status alone cannot disqualify a parent, legal guardian, or relative from being a placement for a foster child. The "Help Separated Families Act of 2012" prohibits immigration status from disqualifying a parent, legal guardian, or relative as a foster child placement. Additionally, the State Plan Requirement allows certain documents from foreign entities to be used for criminal records checks. Section 471(a)(20) of the Social Security Act is amended to require states to accept foreign consulate identification cards or passports for criminal records checks in foster care placements. The Social Security Act now requires states to accept foreign consulate identification cards or passports for criminal records checks in foster care placements. Additionally, caseworkers and supervisors can use foreign identification documents for this purpose as well. STATE CHILD WELFARE AGENCIES ENCOURAGED TO WAIVE REQUIREMENTS FOR PLACING CHILDREN WITH RELATIVES BASED ON MINOR LEGAL INFRACTIONS. STATE PLANS MUST NOTIFY RELATIVES THAT IMMIGRATION STATUS WILL NOT BE QUESTIONED. Section 471(a)(29) of the Social Security Act is amended to protect the immigration status of relatives seeking placement of a child, unless necessary for eligibility for services. Additionally, there is a prohibition on states filing for termination of parental rights in foster care cases involving deported or immigrant-involved parents or relatives, unless specific conditions are met. Section 475(5)(E) of the Social Security Act prohibits states from filing for termination of parental rights in cases involving deported or immigrant-involved parents, unless reasonable efforts have been made to locate and contact the parent or relative. The Social Security Act prohibits states from terminating parental rights for deported or immigrant-involved parents without making efforts to notify and reunify the child with the parent or relative. SEC. 7. EFFECTIVE DATE. The amendments made by this Act will take effect on the 1st day of the 1st fiscal year after enactment and apply to payments under part E of title IV of the Social Security Act for calendar quarters after that date. Delay is allowed if State legislation is needed for State plans to meet the new requirements. Each year of a 2-year legislative session is considered a separate regular session of the State legislature.
